hadith-eng: "Two favors that many of the people squander are health and free time."
question: What are the two blessings that people often neglect or misuse?

hadith-eng: "Who will take these statements from me, so that he may act upon them, or teach one who will act upon them?" So Abu Hurairah said: "I said: 'I shall O Messenger of Allah!' So he (s.a.w) took my hand and enumerated five (things), he said: "Be on guard against the unlawful and you shall be the most worshiping among the people, be satisfied with what Allah has alloted for you and you shall be the richest of the people, be kind to your neighbor and you shall be a believer, love for the people what you love for yourself and you shall be a Muslim. And do not laugh too much, for indeed increased laughter kills the heart."
question: What are the benefits of avoiding unlawful actions in Islam?

hadith-eng: "Race to do works against seven. Are you waiting but for overwhelming poverty, or distracting richness, or debilitating illness, or babbling senility, or sudden death, or the Dajjal, so that hidden evil is what is awaited, or the Hour? The Hour is more calamitous and more bitter." (Daif)
question: What are the seven events or conditions that people are warned to act against in this narration?

hadith-eng: "Increase in remembrance of the severer of pleasures." Meaning death.
question: What is the significance of remembering death in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: When 'Uthman would stop at a grave he would cry until his beard was soaked (in tears). It was said to him: 'The Paradise and the Fire were mentioned and you did not cry, yet you cry because of this?' So he said: 'Indeed the Messenger of Allah said: "Indeed the grave is the first stage among the stages of the Hereafter. So if one is saved from it, then what comes after it is easier than it. And if one is not saved from it, then what comes after it is worse than it." And the Messenger of Allah said: "I have not seen any sight except that the grave is more horrible than it."
question: Why did 'Uthman cry when he stopped at a grave, and what does this indicate about his understanding of the Hereafter?

hadith-eng: "Whoever loves to meet Allah,  Allah loves to meet him. Whoever is averse to meeting Allah, Allah is averse to meeting him."
question: What is the significance of loving to meet Allah in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
"When this Ayah was revealed: And warn your near kindred....(26:214), the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"O Safiyyah bint 'Abdul-Muttalib! O Fatimah bint Muhammed! O Banu 'Abdul-Muttalib! I have no authority on your behalf over Allah for anything. Ask me for whatever you want of my wealth."
question: What is the significance of the Prophet Muhammad's warning to his close relatives regarding their accountability before Allah?

hadith-eng:
"A man who cries out of fearing Allah, will not be put into the Fire until milk returns to the udder; and dust raised in the cause of Allah and the smoke of Jahannam will not be gathered together."

[He said:] There are narrations on this topic from Abu Raihanah and Ibn 'Abbas. [He said:] This Hadith is [Hasan] Sahih. Muhammad bin 'Abdur-Rahman is the Mawla of the family of Talbah, and he is from Al-Madinah, and trustworthy. Shu'bah and Sufyan Ath-Thawri reported from him.
question: What is the significance of fearing Allah in relation to being saved from the Fire?

hadith-eng:
"Indeed I see what you do not see, and I hear what you do not hear. The Heavens moan, and they have the right to moan. There is no spot, the size of four fingers in them, except that there is an angel placing his forehead in it, prostrating to Allah. By Allah! If you knew what I know, then you would laugh little and you would cry much. And you would not taste the pleasures of your women in the beds, and you would go out beseeching Allah. And I wish that I was but a felled tree." 

[Abu 'Eisa said:] There are narrations on this topic from 'Aishah, Abu Hurairah, Ibn 'Abbas, and Anas. [He said:] This Hadith is Hasan Gharib. It has been related through routes other than this, that Abu Dharr said: "I wish that I was a felled tree." And it has been related from Abu Dharr in Mawquf form.
question: What is the significance of the heavens moaning and the presence of angels in prostration according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "If you knew what I know, then you would laugh little and you would cry much."
question: What impact does knowledge of the unseen have on human emotions and behavior?

hadith-eng: "Indeed a man may utter a statement that he does not see any  harm in, but for which he will fall seventy autumns in the Fire."
question: What are the potential consequences of speaking carelessly without considering the harm it may cause?

hadith-eng: "Woe to the one who talks about something to make the people laugh, in which he lies. Woe to him! Woe to him!"
question: What are the consequences of lying to make people laugh?

hadith-eng:
"Glad tidings of Paradise." To which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"You do not know. Perhaps he spoke of what did not concern him or he was greedy with that which would not decrease him."
question: What is the significance of being cautious in assuming someone's fate in the afterlife?

hadith-eng: "Indeed among the excellence of a person's Islam is that he leaves what does not concern him."
question: What is considered an aspect of excellence in a person's practice of Islam?

hadith-eng: "Surely, of the excellence of a person's Islam is that he leaves what does not concern him."
question: What is considered a sign of excellence in a person's practice of Islam?

hadith-eng:
"I heard Bilal bin Al-Harith Al Muzani, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) saying: 'I heard the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) saying:
"Indeed one of you says a statement pleasing to Allah, not realizing that you have achieved what you have achieved. Then for it, Allah writes for him His pleasure until the Day of Meeting Him. And one of you says a statement angering Allah, not realizing that you have achieved what you have achieved. Then for it, Allah writes for him His anger until the Day of Meeting with Him."
question: What is the significance of speaking words that are pleasing to Allah?

hadith-eng: "If the world to Allah was equal to a mosquito's wing, then He would not allow the disbeliever to have a sip of water from it."
question: What does this hadith imply about the value of the world in the sight of Allah?

hadith-eng: "I was with the caravan of those who stopped with the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) at a dead lamb. The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said: 'Do you think that this was insignificant to its owners when they threw it away?' They said:'Yes! It is because of its insignificance that they threw it away O Messenger of Allah!' He said: 'The world is more insignificant to Allah than this to its owners.'"
question: What lesson can be learned about the value of worldly possessions in comparison to their significance to Allah?

hadith-eng:
I heard Mustawrid, a member of Banu Fihr, saying: The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"The world compared to the Hereafter is but like what one of you gets when placing his finger into the sea, so look at what you draw from it."
question: How does the comparison between the world and the Hereafter illustrate the insignificance of worldly life?

hadith-eng: "The world is a prison for the believer and Paradise for the disbeliever."
question: How is the world described for a believer in terms of its challenges and limitations?

hadith-eng: "There are three things for which I swear and narrate to you about, so remember it." He said: "The wealth of a slave (of Allah) shall not be decreased by charity, no slave (of Allah) suffers injustice and is patient with it except that Allah adds to his honor; no slave (of Allah) opens up a door to begging except that Allah opens a door for him to poverty"- or a statement similar- "And I shall narrate to you a narration, so remember it." He said: "The world is only for four persons: A slave whom Allah provides with wealth and knowledge, so he has Taqwa of his Lord with it, nurtures the ties of kinship with it, and he knows that Allah has a right in it. So this is the most virtuous rank. And a slave whom Allah provides with knowledge, but He does not provide with wealth. So he has a truthful intent, saying: 'If I had wealth, then I would do the deeds of so-and-so with it.'  He has his intention, so their rewards are the same. And a slave whom Allah provides with wealth, but He does not provide him with knowledge. [So he] spends his wealth rashly without knowledge, nor having Taqwa of his Lord, nor nurturing the ties of kinship, and he does not know that Allah has a right in it. So this is the most despicable rank. And a slave whom Allah does not provide with wealth nor knowledge, so he says: 'If I had wealth, then I would do the deeds of so-and-so with it.' He has his intention, so their sin is the same."
question: What are the three things that the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) swore about regarding wealth, injustice, and begging?

hadith-eng: "Whoever suffers from destitution and he beseeches the people for it, his destitution shall not end. And whoever suffers from destitution and he beseeches Allah for it, Allah will send provisions to him, sooner or later."
question: What is the significance of seeking help from Allah during times of financial hardship?

hadith-eng: "Mu'awiyah came to Abu Hashim bin 'Uthbah to visit him when he was ill (and dying). He said: 'O Uncle! Why do you cry? Is it from the pangs of death or desire for this world?' He said: 'Neither of these. But the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) had commissioned me with an obligation that I did not abide by. He (s.a.w) said: "It suffices you to gather the wealth of a servant or a rider in the cause of Allah." And (it is only) today I find that I have gathered it.'"
question: What is the significance of fulfilling obligations given by the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "Do not take to the estate, such that you become desirous  of the world."
question: What is the significance of avoiding excessive attachment to worldly possessions in Islam?

hadith-eng: "O Messenger of Allah! Who is the best of the people?" He said: "He whose life is long and his deeds are good."There are narrations on this topic from Abu Hurairah and Jabir.
question: Who is considered the best among people according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "O Messenger of Allah! Which of the people is the best?" He said: "He whose life is long and his deeds are good." He said: "Then which of the people is the worst?" He said: "He whose life is long and his deeds are bad."
question: Who is considered the best person according to the teachings of Islam?

hadith-eng: "The lifespan for my Ummah is from sixty years to seventy [years]."
question: What is the average lifespan mentioned for the Ummah of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "The hour shall not be established until time is constricted, and the year is like a month, a month is like the week, and the week is like the day, and the day is like the hour, and the hour is like the flare of the fire."
question: What are the signs of the approaching Hour in Islamic eschatology?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) grabbed me on part of my body and said: 'Be in the world like a stranger or a passerby, and count   yourself among the inhabitants of the grave.'" Ibn 'Umar said to me: "When you wake up in the morning, then  do not concern  yourself  with the evening. And when you reach the evening, then do not concern yourself with the morning. Take from your health before your illness, and from your life before your death, for indeed O slave of Allah! You do not know  what your description shall be tomorrow." (sahih)
question: What does it mean to live in the world like a stranger or a passerby?

hadith-eng: "This is the son of Adam, and this is his life-span." And he placed his hand at the (height of the) nape of his neck, then he extended it (higher) and said:" From there is what is hoped for, from there is what is hoped for."
question: What does the hadith imply about the life span of the son of Adam?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) passed by us while we were repairing a hut of ours, so he said: 'What is this?' We said:"It has become weak, so we are repairing it.' He said: 'I do not think  but that the matter (of life) is more in fleeting than that."
question: What lesson can be learned about the temporary nature of life from the Prophet's observation?

hadith-eng: "Indeed there is a fitnah for every Ummah, and the Fitnah for my Ummah is wealth."
question: What is the primary trial or test faced by the Muslim community according to the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "If the Son of Adam had a valley of gold, then he would still like to have a second . And nothing fills his mouth but dust, Allah turns to whoever repents."
question: What does the desire for wealth signify about human nature?

hadith-eng: "The heart of an old man remains young because of love for two things: Long life , and much wealth."
question: What are the desires that keep the heart of an elderly person youthful?

hadith-eng: "The Son Of Adan grows old, but two things keep him young: Desire for life and desire for wealth."
question: What are the two desires that remain strong in a person as they age?

hadith-eng: "Abstinence in the world is not by prohibiting (oneself) the lawful nor by neglecting wealth , but  abstinence in the world is that you not hold more firmly to what is in your hand than to what is in the hand of Allah, and that you be more hopeful of the rewards that come with an affliction that you may suffer if it remain with you."
question: What is the true meaning of abstinence in the context of worldly life?

hadith-eng: "There is no right for the son of Adam in other than these things: A house which he lives in, a garment which covers his nakedness, and Jilf (a piece of bread) and water."
question: What are the basic necessities of life according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The mutual increase diverts you". He (s.a.w) said: "The son of Adam says:'My wealth, my wealth, but is there something for you from your wealth besides what you give in charity that remains, or you eat which perishes, or what you wear that grows worn?"
question: What is the significance of charity in Islam according to the teachings of the Prophet?

hadith-eng: "O son of Adam! If you give your surplus it is better for you, and if you keep it, it is worse for you, but there is no harm with what is sufficient. And begin(the giving) with your dependents, and the upper hand (giving) is better than the lower hand (receiving)."
question: What is the significance of giving surplus wealth in Islam?

hadith-eng: "If you were to rely upon Allah with the required reliance, then He would provide for you just as a bird is provided for, it goes out in the morning empty, and returns full."
question: What is the significance of relying on Allah in one's daily life?

hadith-eng: "There were two brothers during the time of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w). One of them used to come to the prophet (s.a.w), and the other had some business. The businessman among them complained to the Prophet (s.a.w) about his brother, so he said:'Perhaps you are provided for because of him.'"
question: What is the significance of supporting those who dedicate their time to religious learning and devotion?

hadith-eng:
"The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"Whoever among you wakes up in the morning secured in his dwelling, healthy in his body, having his food for the day,then it is as if the world has been gathered for him.'"
question: What are the three blessings mentioned that contribute to a person's sense of contentment and security?

hadith-eng: "Indeed the best of my friends to me is the one of meager conditions, whose share is in Salat, worshipping his Lord well and obeying him (even) in private. He is obscure among the people such that the fingers are not pointed towards him. His provisions are only what is sufficient and he is patient with that." Then he tapped with his fingers and said: "His death comes quickly, his mourners are few, and his inheritance is little."With this (the above), chain it is narrated that the Prophet (s.a.w) said: "My Lord presented to me, that He would make the valley of Makkah into gold for me, I said: 'No O Lord! But being filled for a day and hungry for a day"-or he said: "three days" or something like that- "So when I am hungry, I would beseech You and remember You, and when I am full I would be grateful to You and praise You."
question: What qualities make a person a beloved friend to the Prophet according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "He has succeeded who accepts Islam, and is provided with what is sufficient and is made content by Allah."
question: What are the key elements that contribute to a person's success according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Glad tidings to whoever is guided to Islam, his livelihood was sufficient and he was satisfied."
question: What are the benefits of being guided to Islam according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "A man said to the Prophet (s.a.w): 'O Messenger of Allah! By Allah! Indeed I love you!' So he said: 'Consider what you say.' He said: 'By Allah! I indeed love you!' Three times. He said: 'If you do love me, then prepare and arm yourself against poverty. For indeed poverty comes faster upon whoever loves me than the flood to its destination.'"
question: What is the significance of expressing love for the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) in Islam?

hadith-eng: "The poor Muhajirin will enter Paradise before the rich among them by five hundred years."
question: What is the significance of the Muhajirin in Islamic history?

hadith-eng: "O Allah! Cause me to live needy, and cause me to die needy and gather me in the group of the needy on the Day of Resurrection." 'Aishah said: "Why O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Indeed they enter Paradise before their rich by forty autumns. O 'Aishah! Do not turn away the needy even if with a piece of date. O 'Aishah! Love the needy and be near them, for indeed Allah will make you near on the Day of Judgement."
question: What is the significance of living and dying in a state of neediness according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The poor are admitted into Paradise before the rich, by five hundres years, (i.e.) half a day."
question: What is the significance of the time difference in entering Paradise between the poor and the rich?

hadith-eng: "The poor Muslims are admitted into Paradise before their rich by half a day. And that is five hundred years."
question: What is the significance of the time difference in the admission of poor and rich Muslims into Paradise?

hadith-eng: "The poor Muslims are admitted into Paradise before their rich by forty autumns."
question: What is the significance of the time difference in entering Paradise between poor and rich Muslims?

hadith-eng: "I entered upon 'Aishah and she invited me to eat. She said: 'Whenever I eat my fill of food I want to cry and begin crying.' He said: "I said : 'Why?' She said: 'I remember the circumstances under which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) parted from the world. By Allah! He would not eat his fill of bread and meat twice in a day.'"
question: What can be learned about the lifestyle and simplicity of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) from this account?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) did not eat his fill of barley bread on two consecutive days until he was taken (died)."
question: What does the lifestyle of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) teach us about contentment and simplicity?

hadith-eng: "Neither the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) nor his family, ate their fill of wheat bread for three consecutive days until he parted the world."
question: What does this narration indicate about the lifestyle and simplicity of the Prophet Muhammad and his family?

hadith-eng: "There was never a surplus of barley  bread for the inhabitants of the house of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)."
question: What does the scarcity of food in the household of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) indicate about his lifestyle?

hadith-eng: " The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) would spend many consecutive nights and his family did not have supper, and most of the time their bread was barley bread."
question: What does this narration indicate about the lifestyle and simplicity of the Prophet Muhammad's household?

hadith-eng: "O Allah! Make the sustenance of Muhammad's family nourishing."
question: What is the significance of praying for nourishing sustenance in Islam?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (s.a.w) would not store anything  for the morrow."
question: What does the practice of not storing provisions for the next day signify in terms of reliance on Allah?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) never ate on a table, nor did he eat thin bread until he died."
question: What were the eating habits of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) regarding the use of tables?

hadith-eng: "Did the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) eat Naqi – meaning refined (flour)?” So Sahl said: “The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) did not see Naqi until he met Allah.” It was said to him: “Did you have sifters during the time of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)?” He said: “There were no sifters for us.” They said: “How did you prepare the barley?”He said: “We would blow it so (the husk) would fly off of it, then we would add water so we could knead it.” (Hasan)
question: What type of flour did the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) consume during his lifetime?

hadith-eng: "I was among the first men who spilled blood in Allah's cause, and I was among the first men to shoot an arrow in Allah's cause. I saw battles with troops of the Companions of Muhammad (s.a.w). We had nothing to eat except leaves of trees and Al-Hublah, such that one of us would leave droppings like the droppings of sheep and camels. Now Banu Asad have appeared wanting to instruct me in religion, ( then) I would be a loser and have wasted my efforts."
question: What challenges did the early Muslims face in terms of sustenance during battles?

hadith-eng: "I was the first man among the Arabs to shoot an arrow in Allah's cause. I saw that we battled along with the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) and there was no food for us but Al-Hubla and this Samur, such that one of us would leave droppings like the droppings of a sheep. Then Banu Asad appeared wanting to instruct me in religion. I would be a loser and have wasted my efforts."
question: What challenges did early Muslims face in terms of sustenance during battles?

hadith-eng: "We were with Abu Hurarirah and he was wearing two linen garments dyed with red ochre. He blew his nose in one of them and said: 'Excellent! Abu hurairah blows his nose in linens! I saw a time when I would pass out between themimbarof the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) and the dwelling of 'Aishah from overwhelming hunger. Someone came and placed his foot on my neck thinking that I was a mad man, but I was not crazy, It was nothing but hunger." (sahih)
question: What does this narration reveal about the living conditions of Abu Hurairah during the time of the Prophet?

hadith-eng:
'These people are mad' or "possessed." So when the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) finished the Salah, he turned to them and said:
'If you knew what was in store for you with Allah then you would love to be increased in poverty and need.'” Fadalah said: “And on that day, I was with the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w).” (Hasan)
question: What challenges did the Ashab As-suffah face during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (s.a.w) went out during an hour in which he would normally not go out, nor meet with anyone. Then Abu Bakr came to him. So he said:"What brought you O Abu Bakr?" He said: "I came to meet the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) and to look at his face, and to make sure he was safe. It was not long before 'Umar came. He said: "What has brought you O 'Umar ?" He said: "Hunger  O  Messenger of Allah!"He said: "I also experienced some of that" So they went to the home of Abu Al-Haitham At-Taiyyihan Al-Ansari. He was a man with many date-palms and sheep, but he had no servants so they did not find him there. They said to his wife: "Where is your companion?" She said: "He has gone to fetch us some good water." It was not long before Abu Al-Haitham came along hauling to a large water-skin which he put down. Then he came to hug the Prophet (s.a.w) and uttered that his father and mother should be ransomed for him. Then he went to grove of his and he spread out a mat for them. Then he went to a date-palm and returned with a cluster of dates which he put down. The prophet (s.a.w) said: "Why don't you select some ripe dates for us?" He said:  "O Messenger of Allah(s.a.w)! I wanted you to select from the ripe dates and the unripe dates." So they ate and they drank from that water. The Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) said: "By the One in Whose Hand is my soul! This is among the favors which you shall be asked about on the Day of Judgement. Cool shade, tasty ripe dates, and cool water." Abu Al-Haitham left to prepare some food for them. The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Do not slaughter one with milk." So he Slaughtered a small female or male goat and brought it to them so they could eat it. The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Do you have any servants?" He said: "No." So he said: "Then if we get some captives we shall bring them for you." So (later) the Prophet (s.a.w) came with 2 males, there was no third among them and he brought them to Abu Al-Haitham. The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Choose from them." He said: "O Prophet of Allah! Choose for me." So the Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Indeed the one consulted is entrusted. Take this one for I have seen him praying, and encourage him to do well." So Abu Al-Haitham went to his wife and informed her of what the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said. So his wife said: "You will not fulfill what the Prophet (s.a.w) said until you have freed him." So he said: "He is free." So the Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Indeed Allah has not send a Prophet nor made a Khalifah except that he has two groups of supporters, group ordering him to do good, and prohibiting him from evil and a group that never ceases spoiling his affairs. So whoever protected."
question: What can be learned about the importance of companionship and checking on the well-being of others from this narration?

hadith-eng: the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) went out one day accompained by Abu Bakr  and 'Umar. And he mentioned similar to Hadith( no 2369) in meaning, but he did not mention "from Abu Hurairah" in it.
question: Who were the companions that accompanied the Prophet on the day mentioned in the narration?

hadith-eng: "We complained to the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) of hunger and we raised(our garments ) from our stomachs (exposing) a stone (on each of us). So the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) raised (his garment exposing) two stones."
question: What does the act of exposing stones on the stomach signify in the context of hunger and hardship?

hadith-eng: "I heard An-Nu'man bin Bashir saying: 'Do you (people) not have what you wish of food and drink?' I have seen your Prophet and he did not have even enoughdaqal(dry dates) to fill his stomach.'"
question: What does this narration suggest about the lifestyle and contentment of the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ)?

hadith-eng: "Richness is not having many possessions, but richness is being content with oneself."
question: What is the true definition of richness according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Indeed this wealth is green and sweet. Whoever gets what he deserves of it then he shall be blessed in it. And many a person who deals with what he wants for himself, from the wealth of Allah and His Messenger, gets nothing on the Day of Judgment but the Fire."
question: What is the significance of wealth being described as 'green and sweet' in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Cursed be the slave of the Dinar, cursed be the slave of the Dirham."
question: What is the significance of wealth in a person's life according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Two wolves free among sheep are no more destructive to them than a man's desire for wealth and honor is to his religion."
question: How can the desire for wealth and honor impact a person's religious commitment?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) was sleeping upon a mat, then he stood, and the mat had left marks on his side. We said: 'O Messenger of Allah! We said: 'O Messenger of Allah! We could get a bed for you.' He said: 'What do I have to do with the world! I am not in the world but as a rider seeking shade under a tree, then he catches his breath and leaves it.'"
question: What does the hadith imply about the Prophet's (s.a.w) attitude towards worldly comforts and possessions?

hadith-eng: "A man is upon the religion of his friend, so let one of you look at whom he befriends."
question: How does friendship influence a person's religious beliefs and practices?

hadith-eng: "Three follow the deceased, two of them return, and one remains. He is followed by his family, his wealth, and his deeds. So his family and his wealth returns, and his deeds remain."
question: What are the three things that accompany a person after death according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
"I heard the Messenger of Allah (S.a.w) saying:
'The human does not fill any container that is worse than his stomach. It is sufficient for the son of Adam to eat what will support his back. If this is not possible, then a third for food, a third for drink, and third for his breath."
question: What guidance does Islam provide regarding moderation in eating and drinking?

hadith-eng: "Whoever wants to be seen, Allah will show him, And whoever wants to be heard of, Allah will make him heard off." And he narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said: "He who shows no mercy to the people, Allah shows him no mercy."
question: What are the consequences of seeking attention and recognition for one's actions according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng:
" Who is this?" They said: "Abu Hurairah."  (He said):So I got close to him until I was sitting in front of him as he was narrating to the people. When he was silent and alone, I said to him: " I ask youabsolute truth if you would narrate to me a Hadith which you heard from the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w), That you understand and know."
So Abu Hurairah said: "You want me to narrate a Hadith to you which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) narrated to me that I understand and know." Then Abu Hurairah began sobbing profusely. We sat for a while, then he recovered and said: "I shall narrate to you a Hadith which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) narrated in this House, while there was no one with us other than he and I." 
Then, again, Abu Hurairah began sobbing severely. Then he recovered, and wiped his face, and said: "you want me to narrate to you a Hadith which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) narrated while he and I were sitting in this House, and no one was with us but he and I." Then Abu Hurairah began sobbing severely. Then he bent, falling on his face, so I supported him for a long time. Then he recovered and said: "The Messenger of Allah narrated to me that on the Day of Judgement, Allah, Most High, will descend to His slaves t judge between them. Every nation shall be kneeling. The first of those who will be called before him will be a man who memorized the Qur'an, and a man who was killed in Allah's cause, and a wealthy man. Allah will say to the reciter: 'Did I not teach you what I revealed to My Messenger?" He says: 'Of course O Lord!' He says: 'Then what did you do with what you learned?' He said: 'I would stand (in prayer reciting) with it during all hours of the night and all hours of the day.' Then Allah would say to him: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied.'Allah will say to him: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said that so-and-so is a reciter. And that was said.' The person with the wealth will be brought, and Allah will say to him: 'Was I not so generous with you, such that I did not leave you having any need from anyone?' He will say: 'Of course O Lord!' He says: 'Then what did you do with what I gave to you?' He says: 'I would nurture the ties of kinship and give charity.' Then Allah will say to him: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say to him: 'You have lied.' Allah, Most High, will say: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said that so-and-so is so generous, and that was said.' Then the one who was killed in Allah's cause shall be brought, and Allah will say to him : 'For what were you killed?' So he says: 'I was commanded to fight in Your cause ,so I fought until I was killed.' Allah [Most High] will say to him: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say to him: 'You have lied.' Allah [Most High] will say: 'Rather, you wanted it be said that so-and-so is brave, and that was said.' 
"Then the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)hit me on my knees and said: 'O Abu Hurairah! These first three are the creatures of Allah with whom the fire will be enflamed on the Day of Judgement.'"
Al-Walid Abu 'Uthman Al-Mada'ini said: "So 'Uqbah bin Muslim informed me that Shaufaiy, is the one who entered upon Mu'awiyah to inform him about this." Abu Uthman said: 'This has been done with these people, then how about with those who remain among the people?" Then Mu'awiyah begin weeping so intensely, that we thought that he will kill himself with excessive weeping. We said: "This man came to us to cause evil." Then Mu'awiyah recovered, wiped off his face and said: "Allah and His Messenger told the truth: Whosoever desires the life of the world and its glitter, then we shall pay in full (the wages of) their deeds therein, and they shall have no diminution therein. They are those for whom there is nothing in the Hereafter Fire, and vain are the deeds they did therein. And of no effect is that which they used to do."
question: What is the significance of sincerity in one's actions according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Seek refuge in Allah from the Pit of Sorrows." They said: "O Messenger of Allah! What is the Pit of Sorrows?" He said: "gorge in Hell from which Hell seeks Allah's refuge a Hundred times every day." It was said: "O Messenger of Allah! Who shall enter it?" He said: "The reciters who were showing off with their deeds."
question: What is the significance of seeking refuge in Allah from specific punishments in the afterlife?

hadith-eng: "O Messenger of Allah! A man does a deed and conceals it, but when it is discovered that he did it, he is happy about that." He said: " The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said: 'He receives two rewards: A reward in its concealment, and a reward in its publicity.'"
question: What are the rewards associated with performing a good deed in secret and having it later become known?

hadith-eng: " O Messenger of Allah! When will the Hour be established?" So the Propher (s.a.w) stood to perform Salat and when he was finished his Salat he said: "Where is the one who asked when the hour will be established?" The man said: "It was I, O Mesenger of Allah!" He said: "What have you prepared for it?" He said: "O Messenger of allah! I have not prepared very much of salat nor fasting for it, but I love Allah and His Messenger." So the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) said: "A man shall be with whom ever he loves, and you shall be with whomever you love." So after the advent of Islam, I did not see that anything brought the Muslims more happiness than that.
question: What is the significance of love for Allah and His Messenger in determining one's companionship in the Hereafter?

hadith-eng: " A man shall be with whoever he loves, and for him shall be what he has earned."
question: What is the significance of love in determining one's companionship in the afterlife?

hadith-eng: " O Muhammad! A man loves the people but does not catch up to them (in deeds)." So the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) said: "A man shall be with whomever he loves."
question: What is the significance of love for others in determining one's companionship in the afterlife?

hadith-eng: "Indeed Allah Most High says: 'I am as My slave thinks of Me, and I am with him when He  calls upon Me.'"
question: What does the belief in Allah's nature and attributes imply about a person's relationship with Him?

hadith-eng: "Righteouness is good behaviour, and sin is what fluctuates in your chest, and you would hate that the people discovered it about you."
question: What is considered righteousness in terms of behavior according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Allah, the Mighty and Sublime, said: 'Those who love each other for the sake of My Majesty shall be upon podiums of light, and they will be admired by the Prophets and the martyrs.'"
question: What is the significance of loving each other for the sake of Allah's Majesty in Islam?

hadith-eng: "Seven shall be shaded by Allah under his shade on a day in which there is no shade except His Shade: A just Imam, a young person raised upon worshiping  Allah, a man whose heart is attached to the Masjid when he leaves from it until he returns from it, two men who love each other for Allah's sake, coming together upon that, and parting upon that, a man who remembers Allah in privacy and his eyes swell with tears, a man invited by a woman of status and beauty, but he says: 'I fear Allah, Mighty and Sublime is He,' and a man who conceals the charity he gives such that his left hand does not know what his right hand has spent."
question: Who are the individuals promised shade by Allah on the Day of Judgment?

hadith-eng: "When one of you loves his brother,then let him inform him of it."
question: What is the significance of expressing love towards one's brother in Islam?

hadith-eng: "A man stood and praised one of the 'Amirs so Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad threw dust in his face and said: 'The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) ordered us to throw dust in the faces of those who praise others.'"
question: What is the Islamic perspective on excessive praise of individuals in positions of authority?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) ordered us to throw dut in the mouths of those who praise others."
question: What is the Islamic perspective on excessive praise of others?

hadith-eng: "Do not accompany except a believer, and do not serve your food except to one with Taqwa."
question: What are the characteristics of a person one should choose as a companion?

hadith-eng: "When Allah wants good for his slave, He hastens his punishment in the world. And when He wants bad for His slave, He withholds his sins from him until he appears before Him on the Day of Judgement."And with this (same) chain, (it was reported) from the Prophet (ﷺ) who said: "Indeed greater reward comes with greater trial. And indeed, when Allah loves a people He subjects them to trials, so whoever is content, then for him is pleasure, and whoever is discontent, then for him is wrath."
question: What is the significance of trials and tribulations in a believer's life according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "I have not seen ailment effecting anyone worse than upon the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) experience illness compared to others?

hadith-eng:
"O Messenger of Allah(s.a.w)! Which of the people is tried most severely?" He said:
"The Prophets, then those nearest to them, then those nearest to them. A man is tried according to his religion; if he is firm in his religion, then his trials are more severe, and if he is frail in his religion, then he is tried according to the strength of his religion. The servant shall continue to be tried until he is left walking upon the earth without any sins."
question: Who are considered to be the people most severely tested in life?

hadith-eng: "Trials will not cease afflicting the believing man and the believing woman in their self, children, and wealth, until they meet Allah without having any sin."
question: What is the significance of trials and tribulations in the life of a believer?

hadith-eng: "Indeed Allah [Most High] said: 'When I take My slave's sight in the world, then there shall be no reward for him with Me except Paradise.'"
question: What is the significance of patience and acceptance of trials in Islam?

hadith-eng: "Allah, Mighty and Sublime is He, said: 'For whomever I take his sight, and he is patient and seeking a reward, I shall not be satisfied with any reward for him less than Paradise.'"
question: What is the significance of patience in Islam when facing personal hardships?

hadith-eng:
"On the Day of Judgement, when the people who were tried (in this world) are given their rewards, the people who were pardoned (in life), will wish that their skins had been cut off with scissors while they were in the world."

This Hadith is Gharib, we do not know of it with this chain except through this route. Some of them have reported something similar to this Hadith from Al-A`mash, from Talhah bin Musarrif from Masruq.
question: What is the significance of trials and tribulations in this world according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "There is no one who dies but he shall regret." They said: "What shall he regret over O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "If he was a good doer, he regrets that he did not do more, and if he was an evil doer, he regrets that he did not stop."
question: What are the feelings of regret experienced by individuals after death according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "In the end of time there shall come men who will swindle the world with religion, decieving the people in soft skins of sheep, their tongues are sweeter than sugar and their hearts are the hearts of wolves. Allah [Mighty and Sublime is He] says: 'Is it me you try to delude or is it against me whom you conspire? By Me, I swear to send upon these people,among them, a Fitnah that leaves them utterly devoid of reason."
question: What characteristics are described for those who misuse religion for worldly gain?

hadith-eng: "Indeed Allah, Most High, said:'I have created creatures whose tongues are sweeter than honey and their hearts are more bitter than aloes. So by Me, I swear to abase them with a Fitnah, leaving them utterly devoid of reason. Is it Me whom they try to delude, or it is  against Me whom they conspire?'"
question: What does the hadith imply about the nature of some people's speech compared to their inner intentions?

hadith-eng:
"I said: 'O Messenger of Allah! What is the means to salvation?' He said:
'That you control your tongue, suffice yourself your house, and cry over your sins.'"
question: What are the key actions recommended for achieving salvation in Islam?

hadith-eng: "When the son of Adam wakes up in the morning, all of his body parts bow to the tongue and say: 'Fear Allah regarding us, we are only part of you. If you are straight we are straight and if you are crooked we are crooked."
question: What is the significance of the tongue in influencing the actions of the body according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Whoever guarantees for me what is between his jaws and what is between his legs, I shall guarantee Paradise for him."
question: What is the significance of controlling one's speech in Islam?

hadith-eng: "For whomever Allah protects against the evil of what is between his jaws and the evil of what is between his legs, he shall enter Paradise."
question: What are the consequences of controlling one's speech and desires in Islam?

hadith-eng:
I said: "O Messenger of Allah! Inform me about a matter that I may hold fast to." He said:
'Say: My Lord is Allah, then be steadfast.' I said: "O Messenger of Allah! What do you fear most for me?" So he took hold of his tongue and said: 'This.'"
question: What is the significance of declaring one's faith in Allah and maintaining steadfastness?

hadith-eng: "Do not talk too much without remembrance of Allah. Indeed excessive talking without remembrance of Allah hardens the heart. And indeed the furthest of people from Allah is the harsh-hearted."
question: What are the consequences of excessive talking without the remembrance of Allah?

hadith-eng: "The son of Adam's speech is against him not for him, except for commanding good, or forbidding evil, or remembrance of Allah."
question: What are the exceptions to the rule that a person's speech is generally against him?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) made a bond of brotherhood  between Salman and Abu Ad-Darda. Salman went to visit Abu Ad-Darda, and saw Umm Ad-Darda wearing shabby clothes, So he said: 'Why are you wearing such shabby clothes?' She said: 'Your brother Abu Ad-Darda has no interest in the world.' So when Abu Ad-Darda arrived, he prepared some food for him (Salman) and said: 'Eat, for I am fasting.' He said: 'I shall not eat until you eat.'" He said: "So he ate. When night came Abu Ad-Darda started to leave and stand (in prayer), but Salman said to him: 'Sleep.' So he slept. Then he went to stand (in prayer) but he said to him: 'Sleep'. So he slept. When the morning (Fajr) came,Salman said: 'Get up now.'So he got up to perform Salat. Then he (Salman) said: 'Indeed your self has a right upon you, your Lord has a right upon you, your guest has a right upon you, and your family has a right upon you. So give each the right they are due. The Prophet (s.a.w), and that was mentioned to him, so he said: 'Salman has told the truth.'"
question: What is the significance of balancing religious duties with personal and social responsibilities in Islam?

hadith-eng: "Mu'awiyah wrote a letter to 'Aishah, that: 'Write a letter to advise me , and do not overburden me.'" He said: "So 'Aishah [may Allah be pleased with her]wrote to Mu'awiyah: 'Peace be upon you. As for what follows: Indeed I heard the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) saying: Whoever seeks Allah's pleasure by the people's wrath, Allah will suffice him from the people. And who ever seeks the people's pleasure by Allah's wrath, Allah will entrust him to the people. And Peace be upon you.'"
question: What is the significance of seeking Allah's pleasure over people's approval in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Two favors that many of the people squander are health and free time."
question: How can individuals make the most of their health and free time?

hadith-eng: "Who will take these statements from me, so that he may act upon them, or teach one who will act upon them?" So Abu Hurairah said: "I said: 'I shall O Messenger of Allah!' So he (s.a.w) took my hand and enumerated five (things), he said: "Be on guard against the unlawful and you shall be the most worshiping among the people, be satisfied with what Allah has alloted for you and you shall be the richest of the people, be kind to your neighbor and you shall be a believer, love for the people what you love for yourself and you shall be a Muslim. And do not laugh too much, for indeed increased laughter kills the heart."
question: How can contentment with one's provisions lead to a sense of richness?

hadith-eng: "Race to do works against seven. Are you waiting but for overwhelming poverty, or distracting richness, or debilitating illness, or babbling senility, or sudden death, or the Dajjal, so that hidden evil is what is awaited, or the Hour? The Hour is more calamitous and more bitter." (Daif)
question: How does overwhelming poverty impact a person's ability to perform good deeds?

hadith-eng: "Increase in remembrance of the severer of pleasures." Meaning death.
question: How does the remembrance of death affect a person's behavior and lifestyle?

hadith-eng: When 'Uthman would stop at a grave he would cry until his beard was soaked (in tears). It was said to him: 'The Paradise and the Fire were mentioned and you did not cry, yet you cry because of this?' So he said: 'Indeed the Messenger of Allah said: "Indeed the grave is the first stage among the stages of the Hereafter. So if one is saved from it, then what comes after it is easier than it. And if one is not saved from it, then what comes after it is worse than it." And the Messenger of Allah said: "I have not seen any sight except that the grave is more horrible than it."
question: What is the significance of the grave in the stages of the Hereafter according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Whoever loves to meet Allah,  Allah loves to meet him. Whoever is averse to meeting Allah, Allah is averse to meeting him."
question: How does one's attitude towards meeting Allah reflect their spiritual state?

hadith-eng:
"When this Ayah was revealed: And warn your near kindred....(26:214), the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"O Safiyyah bint 'Abdul-Muttalib! O Fatimah bint Muhammed! O Banu 'Abdul-Muttalib! I have no authority on your behalf over Allah for anything. Ask me for whatever you want of my wealth."
question: How does the Prophet Muhammad emphasize the individual responsibility of each person in their relationship with Allah?

hadith-eng:
"A man who cries out of fearing Allah, will not be put into the Fire until milk returns to the udder; and dust raised in the cause of Allah and the smoke of Jahannam will not be gathered together."

[He said:] There are narrations on this topic from Abu Raihanah and Ibn 'Abbas. [He said:] This Hadith is [Hasan] Sahih. Muhammad bin 'Abdur-Rahman is the Mawla of the family of Talbah, and he is from Al-Madinah, and trustworthy. Shu'bah and Sufyan Ath-Thawri reported from him.
question: How does crying out of fear of Allah impact a person's fate in the Hereafter?

hadith-eng:
"Indeed I see what you do not see, and I hear what you do not hear. The Heavens moan, and they have the right to moan. There is no spot, the size of four fingers in them, except that there is an angel placing his forehead in it, prostrating to Allah. By Allah! If you knew what I know, then you would laugh little and you would cry much. And you would not taste the pleasures of your women in the beds, and you would go out beseeching Allah. And I wish that I was but a felled tree." 

[Abu 'Eisa said:] There are narrations on this topic from 'Aishah, Abu Hurairah, Ibn 'Abbas, and Anas. [He said:] This Hadith is Hasan Gharib. It has been related through routes other than this, that Abu Dharr said: "I wish that I was a felled tree." And it has been related from Abu Dharr in Mawquf form.
question: How does the knowledge of the unseen affect a person's behavior and emotions in Islam?

hadith-eng: "If you knew what I know, then you would laugh little and you would cry much."
question: How does awareness of certain realities influence a person's tendency to laugh or cry?

hadith-eng: "Indeed a man may utter a statement that he does not see any  harm in, but for which he will fall seventy autumns in the Fire."
question: How can a seemingly harmless statement lead to severe repercussions in the afterlife?

hadith-eng: "Woe to the one who talks about something to make the people laugh, in which he lies. Woe to him! Woe to him!"
question: How does Islam view the act of lying for entertainment purposes?

hadith-eng:
"Glad tidings of Paradise." To which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"You do not know. Perhaps he spoke of what did not concern him or he was greedy with that which would not decrease him."
question: How can speaking about matters that do not concern a person affect their spiritual state?

hadith-eng: "Indeed among the excellence of a person's Islam is that he leaves what does not concern him."
question: How can a person improve their Islamic character according to the teachings of the Prophet?

hadith-eng: "Surely, of the excellence of a person's Islam is that he leaves what does not concern him."
question: How can a person improve their Islamic character according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng:
"I heard Bilal bin Al-Harith Al Muzani, the Companion of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) saying: 'I heard the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) saying:
"Indeed one of you says a statement pleasing to Allah, not realizing that you have achieved what you have achieved. Then for it, Allah writes for him His pleasure until the Day of Meeting Him. And one of you says a statement angering Allah, not realizing that you have achieved what you have achieved. Then for it, Allah writes for him His anger until the Day of Meeting with Him."
question: How can a person's words lead to Allah's pleasure or anger?

hadith-eng: "If the world to Allah was equal to a mosquito's wing, then He would not allow the disbeliever to have a sip of water from it."
question: How does this narration illustrate the insignificance of worldly possessions compared to spiritual beliefs?

hadith-eng: "I was with the caravan of those who stopped with the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) at a dead lamb. The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said: 'Do you think that this was insignificant to its owners when they threw it away?' They said:'Yes! It is because of its insignificance that they threw it away O Messenger of Allah!' He said: 'The world is more insignificant to Allah than this to its owners.'"
question: How does the insignificance of the world to Allah affect a believer's perspective on material wealth?

hadith-eng:
I heard Mustawrid, a member of Banu Fihr, saying: The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"The world compared to the Hereafter is but like what one of you gets when placing his finger into the sea, so look at what you draw from it."
question: What metaphor is used to describe the relationship between this world and the Hereafter?

hadith-eng: "The world is a prison for the believer and Paradise for the disbeliever."
question: What does the concept of the world being a 'prison' imply for a believer's life and actions?

hadith-eng: "There are three things for which I swear and narrate to you about, so remember it." He said: "The wealth of a slave (of Allah) shall not be decreased by charity, no slave (of Allah) suffers injustice and is patient with it except that Allah adds to his honor; no slave (of Allah) opens up a door to begging except that Allah opens a door for him to poverty"- or a statement similar- "And I shall narrate to you a narration, so remember it." He said: "The world is only for four persons: A slave whom Allah provides with wealth and knowledge, so he has Taqwa of his Lord with it, nurtures the ties of kinship with it, and he knows that Allah has a right in it. So this is the most virtuous rank. And a slave whom Allah provides with knowledge, but He does not provide with wealth. So he has a truthful intent, saying: 'If I had wealth, then I would do the deeds of so-and-so with it.'  He has his intention, so their rewards are the same. And a slave whom Allah provides with wealth, but He does not provide him with knowledge. [So he] spends his wealth rashly without knowledge, nor having Taqwa of his Lord, nor nurturing the ties of kinship, and he does not know that Allah has a right in it. So this is the most despicable rank. And a slave whom Allah does not provide with wealth nor knowledge, so he says: 'If I had wealth, then I would do the deeds of so-and-so with it.' He has his intention, so their sin is the same."
question: How does charity affect the wealth of a person according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Whoever suffers from destitution and he beseeches the people for it, his destitution shall not end. And whoever suffers from destitution and he beseeches Allah for it, Allah will send provisions to him, sooner or later."
question: How does relying on people for financial assistance affect one's situation according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Mu'awiyah came to Abu Hashim bin 'Uthbah to visit him when he was ill (and dying). He said: 'O Uncle! Why do you cry? Is it from the pangs of death or desire for this world?' He said: 'Neither of these. But the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) had commissioned me with an obligation that I did not abide by. He (s.a.w) said: "It suffices you to gather the wealth of a servant or a rider in the cause of Allah." And (it is only) today I find that I have gathered it.'"
question: How does the concept of wealth accumulation relate to one's duties in the cause of Allah?

hadith-eng: "Do not take to the estate, such that you become desirous  of the world."
question: How can the desire for worldly wealth impact a person's spiritual life?

hadith-eng: "O Messenger of Allah! Who is the best of the people?" He said: "He whose life is long and his deeds are good."There are narrations on this topic from Abu Hurairah and Jabir.
question: What qualities contribute to a person being regarded as the best in society?

hadith-eng: "O Messenger of Allah! Which of the people is the best?" He said: "He whose life is long and his deeds are good." He said: "Then which of the people is the worst?" He said: "He whose life is long and his deeds are bad."
question: What characteristics define the worst person in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The lifespan for my Ummah is from sixty years to seventy [years]."
question: How does the lifespan of the Ummah compare to the lifespans of previous communities?

hadith-eng: "The hour shall not be established until time is constricted, and the year is like a month, a month is like the week, and the week is like the day, and the day is like the hour, and the hour is like the flare of the fire."
question: How is the concept of time perceived in the context of the end times?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) grabbed me on part of my body and said: 'Be in the world like a stranger or a passerby, and count   yourself among the inhabitants of the grave.'" Ibn 'Umar said to me: "When you wake up in the morning, then  do not concern  yourself  with the evening. And when you reach the evening, then do not concern yourself with the morning. Take from your health before your illness, and from your life before your death, for indeed O slave of Allah! You do not know  what your description shall be tomorrow." (sahih)
question: How can one prepare for the afterlife according to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "This is the son of Adam, and this is his life-span." And he placed his hand at the (height of the) nape of his neck, then he extended it (higher) and said:" From there is what is hoped for, from there is what is hoped for."
question: How does the hadith describe the expectations or hopes of a person regarding their life?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) passed by us while we were repairing a hut of ours, so he said: 'What is this?' We said:"It has become weak, so we are repairing it.' He said: 'I do not think  but that the matter (of life) is more in fleeting than that."
question: How does the Prophet's statement reflect on the priorities one should have in life?

hadith-eng: "Indeed there is a fitnah for every Ummah, and the Fitnah for my Ummah is wealth."
question: How does wealth serve as a source of temptation or trial for people?

hadith-eng: "If the Son of Adam had a valley of gold, then he would still like to have a second . And nothing fills his mouth but dust, Allah turns to whoever repents."
question: How does the pursuit of material wealth relate to human satisfaction?

hadith-eng: "The heart of an old man remains young because of love for two things: Long life , and much wealth."
question: How does the love for long life influence a person's heart according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The Son Of Adan grows old, but two things keep him young: Desire for life and desire for wealth."
question: How do the desires for life and wealth impact a person's behavior as they grow older?

hadith-eng: "Abstinence in the world is not by prohibiting (oneself) the lawful nor by neglecting wealth , but  abstinence in the world is that you not hold more firmly to what is in your hand than to what is in the hand of Allah, and that you be more hopeful of the rewards that come with an affliction that you may suffer if it remain with you."
question: How does one balance lawful enjoyment and spiritual abstinence?

hadith-eng: "There is no right for the son of Adam in other than these things: A house which he lives in, a garment which covers his nakedness, and Jilf (a piece of bread) and water."
question: How does Islam define the essential rights of a human being?

hadith-eng: "The mutual increase diverts you". He (s.a.w) said: "The son of Adam says:'My wealth, my wealth, but is there something for you from your wealth besides what you give in charity that remains, or you eat which perishes, or what you wear that grows worn?"
question: How does the concept of wealth and its usage relate to the teachings of the Prophet?

hadith-eng: "O son of Adam! If you give your surplus it is better for you, and if you keep it, it is worse for you, but there is no harm with what is sufficient. And begin(the giving) with your dependents, and the upper hand (giving) is better than the lower hand (receiving)."
question: How does keeping surplus wealth affect a person according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "If you were to rely upon Allah with the required reliance, then He would provide for you just as a bird is provided for, it goes out in the morning empty, and returns full."
question: How does the example of a bird illustrate the concept of reliance on Allah?

hadith-eng: "There were two brothers during the time of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w). One of them used to come to the prophet (s.a.w), and the other had some business. The businessman among them complained to the Prophet (s.a.w) about his brother, so he said:'Perhaps you are provided for because of him.'"
question: How can the actions of one family member impact the provision and blessings for the entire family?

hadith-eng:
"The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"Whoever among you wakes up in the morning secured in his dwelling, healthy in his body, having his food for the day,then it is as if the world has been gathered for him.'"
question: How does having food for the day relate to one's perception of wealth and abundance?

hadith-eng: "Indeed the best of my friends to me is the one of meager conditions, whose share is in Salat, worshipping his Lord well and obeying him (even) in private. He is obscure among the people such that the fingers are not pointed towards him. His provisions are only what is sufficient and he is patient with that." Then he tapped with his fingers and said: "His death comes quickly, his mourners are few, and his inheritance is little."With this (the above), chain it is narrated that the Prophet (s.a.w) said: "My Lord presented to me, that He would make the valley of Makkah into gold for me, I said: 'No O Lord! But being filled for a day and hungry for a day"-or he said: "three days" or something like that- "So when I am hungry, I would beseech You and remember You, and when I am full I would be grateful to You and praise You."
question: How does patience with limited provisions reflect one's faith and devotion in Islam?

hadith-eng: "He has succeeded who accepts Islam, and is provided with what is sufficient and is made content by Allah."
question: How does contentment play a role in achieving success in life?

hadith-eng: "Glad tidings to whoever is guided to Islam, his livelihood was sufficient and he was satisfied."
question: How does contentment with one's livelihood relate to happiness in Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "A man said to the Prophet (s.a.w): 'O Messenger of Allah! By Allah! Indeed I love you!' So he said: 'Consider what you say.' He said: 'By Allah! I indeed love you!' Three times. He said: 'If you do love me, then prepare and arm yourself against poverty. For indeed poverty comes faster upon whoever loves me than the flood to its destination.'"
question: How does the love for the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) relate to the concept of poverty in this narration?

hadith-eng: "The poor Muhajirin will enter Paradise before the rich among them by five hundred years."
question: How does wealth impact one's position in the afterlife according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "O Allah! Cause me to live needy, and cause me to die needy and gather me in the group of the needy on the Day of Resurrection." 'Aishah said: "Why O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Indeed they enter Paradise before their rich by forty autumns. O 'Aishah! Do not turn away the needy even if with a piece of date. O 'Aishah! Love the needy and be near them, for indeed Allah will make you near on the Day of Judgement."
question: Why do the needy enter Paradise before the rich, and what is the time difference mentioned?

hadith-eng: "The poor are admitted into Paradise before the rich, by five hundres years, (i.e.) half a day."
question: How does this narration reflect on the virtues of poverty in Islam?

hadith-eng: "The poor Muslims are admitted into Paradise before their rich by half a day. And that is five hundred years."
question: How does the concept of wealth affect one's entry into Paradise according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "The poor Muslims are admitted into Paradise before their rich by forty autumns."
question: How does wealth impact the journey to Paradise according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "I entered upon 'Aishah and she invited me to eat. She said: 'Whenever I eat my fill of food I want to cry and begin crying.' He said: "I said : 'Why?' She said: 'I remember the circumstances under which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) parted from the world. By Allah! He would not eat his fill of bread and meat twice in a day.'"
question: How did 'Aishah's memories of the Prophet's lifestyle affect her emotions and actions?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) did not eat his fill of barley bread on two consecutive days until he was taken (died)."
question: How can the eating habits of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) serve as a model for moderation in daily life?

hadith-eng: "Neither the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) nor his family, ate their fill of wheat bread for three consecutive days until he parted the world."
question: How does the eating habits of the Prophet Muhammad reflect on his character and teachings?

hadith-eng: "There was never a surplus of barley  bread for the inhabitants of the house of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)."
question: How does the simplicity of the Prophet's household serve as an example for Muslims?

hadith-eng: " The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) would spend many consecutive nights and his family did not have supper, and most of the time their bread was barley bread."
question: How does the consumption of barley bread reflect the economic conditions of the Prophet's family?

hadith-eng: "O Allah! Make the sustenance of Muhammad's family nourishing."
question: How does the concept of sustenance relate to the family of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (s.a.w) would not store anything  for the morrow."
question: How does the concept of living day-to-day relate to the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) never ate on a table, nor did he eat thin bread until he died."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) approach the consumption of thin bread during his lifetime?

hadith-eng: "Did the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) eat Naqi – meaning refined (flour)?” So Sahl said: “The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) did not see Naqi until he met Allah.” It was said to him: “Did you have sifters during the time of the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)?” He said: “There were no sifters for us.” They said: “How did you prepare the barley?”He said: “We would blow it so (the husk) would fly off of it, then we would add water so we could knead it.” (Hasan)
question: Were sifters used for preparing flour during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w)?

hadith-eng: "I was among the first men who spilled blood in Allah's cause, and I was among the first men to shoot an arrow in Allah's cause. I saw battles with troops of the Companions of Muhammad (s.a.w). We had nothing to eat except leaves of trees and Al-Hublah, such that one of us would leave droppings like the droppings of sheep and camels. Now Banu Asad have appeared wanting to instruct me in religion, ( then) I would be a loser and have wasted my efforts."
question: How did the early companions of the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) demonstrate their dedication to the cause of Islam?

hadith-eng: "I was the first man among the Arabs to shoot an arrow in Allah's cause. I saw that we battled along with the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) and there was no food for us but Al-Hubla and this Samur, such that one of us would leave droppings like the droppings of a sheep. Then Banu Asad appeared wanting to instruct me in religion. I would be a loser and have wasted my efforts."
question: How did early Muslims demonstrate their commitment to Allah's cause?

hadith-eng: "We were with Abu Hurarirah and he was wearing two linen garments dyed with red ochre. He blew his nose in one of them and said: 'Excellent! Abu hurairah blows his nose in linens! I saw a time when I would pass out between themimbarof the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) and the dwelling of 'Aishah from overwhelming hunger. Someone came and placed his foot on my neck thinking that I was a mad man, but I was not crazy, It was nothing but hunger." (sahih)
question: How does this account illustrate the humility and gratitude of Abu Hurairah despite his past hardships?

hadith-eng:
'These people are mad' or "possessed." So when the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) finished the Salah, he turned to them and said:
'If you knew what was in store for you with Allah then you would love to be increased in poverty and need.'” Fadalah said: “And on that day, I was with the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w).” (Hasan)
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (s.a.w) address the misconceptions of the Bedouins regarding the Ashab As-suffah?

hadith-eng: "The Prophet (s.a.w) went out during an hour in which he would normally not go out, nor meet with anyone. Then Abu Bakr came to him. So he said:"What brought you O Abu Bakr?" He said: "I came to meet the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) and to look at his face, and to make sure he was safe. It was not long before 'Umar came. He said: "What has brought you O 'Umar ?" He said: "Hunger  O  Messenger of Allah!"He said: "I also experienced some of that" So they went to the home of Abu Al-Haitham At-Taiyyihan Al-Ansari. He was a man with many date-palms and sheep, but he had no servants so they did not find him there. They said to his wife: "Where is your companion?" She said: "He has gone to fetch us some good water." It was not long before Abu Al-Haitham came along hauling to a large water-skin which he put down. Then he came to hug the Prophet (s.a.w) and uttered that his father and mother should be ransomed for him. Then he went to grove of his and he spread out a mat for them. Then he went to a date-palm and returned with a cluster of dates which he put down. The prophet (s.a.w) said: "Why don't you select some ripe dates for us?" He said:  "O Messenger of Allah(s.a.w)! I wanted you to select from the ripe dates and the unripe dates." So they ate and they drank from that water. The Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) said: "By the One in Whose Hand is my soul! This is among the favors which you shall be asked about on the Day of Judgement. Cool shade, tasty ripe dates, and cool water." Abu Al-Haitham left to prepare some food for them. The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Do not slaughter one with milk." So he Slaughtered a small female or male goat and brought it to them so they could eat it. The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Do you have any servants?" He said: "No." So he said: "Then if we get some captives we shall bring them for you." So (later) the Prophet (s.a.w) came with 2 males, there was no third among them and he brought them to Abu Al-Haitham. The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Choose from them." He said: "O Prophet of Allah! Choose for me." So the Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Indeed the one consulted is entrusted. Take this one for I have seen him praying, and encourage him to do well." So Abu Al-Haitham went to his wife and informed her of what the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said. So his wife said: "You will not fulfill what the Prophet (s.a.w) said until you have freed him." So he said: "He is free." So the Prophet (s.a.w) said: "Indeed Allah has not send a Prophet nor made a Khalifah except that he has two groups of supporters, group ordering him to do good, and prohibiting him from evil and a group that never ceases spoiling his affairs. So whoever protected."
question: How does the hadith illustrate the concept of hospitality and generosity in Islam?

hadith-eng: the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) went out one day accompained by Abu Bakr  and 'Umar. And he mentioned similar to Hadith( no 2369) in meaning, but he did not mention "from Abu Hurairah" in it.
question: What is the significance of the Prophet being accompanied by specific companions in certain events?

hadith-eng: "We complained to the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) of hunger and we raised(our garments ) from our stomachs (exposing) a stone (on each of us). So the Messenger of Allah(s.a.w) raised (his garment exposing) two stones."
question: How did the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) demonstrate empathy and solidarity with his companions during times of difficulty?

hadith-eng: "I heard An-Nu'man bin Bashir saying: 'Do you (people) not have what you wish of food and drink?' I have seen your Prophet and he did not have even enoughdaqal(dry dates) to fill his stomach.'"
question: How does this narration reflect on the simplicity and humility of the Prophet's life?

hadith-eng: "Richness is not having many possessions, but richness is being content with oneself."
question: How does contentment contribute to a person's sense of wealth?

hadith-eng: "Indeed this wealth is green and sweet. Whoever gets what he deserves of it then he shall be blessed in it. And many a person who deals with what he wants for himself, from the wealth of Allah and His Messenger, gets nothing on the Day of Judgment but the Fire."
question: How does one ensure that their wealth is blessed according to Islamic principles?

hadith-eng: "Cursed be the slave of the Dinar, cursed be the slave of the Dirham."
question: How can attachment to material wealth affect one's spiritual well-being?

hadith-eng: "Two wolves free among sheep are no more destructive to them than a man's desire for wealth and honor is to his religion."
question: What analogy is used to describe the effect of worldly desires on one's faith?

hadith-eng: "The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) was sleeping upon a mat, then he stood, and the mat had left marks on his side. We said: 'O Messenger of Allah! We said: 'O Messenger of Allah! We could get a bed for you.' He said: 'What do I have to do with the world! I am not in the world but as a rider seeking shade under a tree, then he catches his breath and leaves it.'"
question: How does the metaphor of a rider seeking shade under a tree illustrate the transient nature of life?

hadith-eng: "A man is upon the religion of his friend, so let one of you look at whom he befriends."
question: What criteria should one consider when choosing friends according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Three follow the deceased, two of them return, and one remains. He is followed by his family, his wealth, and his deeds. So his family and his wealth returns, and his deeds remain."
question: Which of the three things that follow a deceased person remains with them after death?

hadith-eng:
"I heard the Messenger of Allah (S.a.w) saying:
'The human does not fill any container that is worse than his stomach. It is sufficient for the son of Adam to eat what will support his back. If this is not possible, then a third for food, a third for drink, and third for his breath."
question: How does overeating affect a person's physical and spiritual well-being according to Islamic teachings?

hadith-eng: "Whoever wants to be seen, Allah will show him, And whoever wants to be heard of, Allah will make him heard off." And he narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said: "He who shows no mercy to the people, Allah shows him no mercy."
question: How does the concept of mercy towards others relate to receiving mercy from Allah?

hadith-eng:
" Who is this?" They said: "Abu Hurairah."  (He said):So I got close to him until I was sitting in front of him as he was narrating to the people. When he was silent and alone, I said to him: " I ask youabsolute truth if you would narrate to me a Hadith which you heard from the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w), That you understand and know."
So Abu Hurairah said: "You want me to narrate a Hadith to you which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) narrated to me that I understand and know." Then Abu Hurairah began sobbing profusely. We sat for a while, then he recovered and said: "I shall narrate to you a Hadith which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) narrated in this House, while there was no one with us other than he and I." 
Then, again, Abu Hurairah began sobbing severely. Then he recovered, and wiped his face, and said: "you want me to narrate to you a Hadith which the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) narrated while he and I were sitting in this House, and no one was with us but he and I." Then Abu Hurairah began sobbing severely. Then he bent, falling on his face, so I supported him for a long time. Then he recovered and said: "The Messenger of Allah narrated to me that on the Day of Judgement, Allah, Most High, will descend to His slaves t judge between them. Every nation shall be kneeling. The first of those who will be called before him will be a man who memorized the Qur'an, and a man who was killed in Allah's cause, and a wealthy man. Allah will say to the reciter: 'Did I not teach you what I revealed to My Messenger?" He says: 'Of course O Lord!' He says: 'Then what did you do with what you learned?' He said: 'I would stand (in prayer reciting) with it during all hours of the night and all hours of the day.' Then Allah would say to him: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied.'Allah will say to him: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said that so-and-so is a reciter. And that was said.' The person with the wealth will be brought, and Allah will say to him: 'Was I not so generous with you, such that I did not leave you having any need from anyone?' He will say: 'Of course O Lord!' He says: 'Then what did you do with what I gave to you?' He says: 'I would nurture the ties of kinship and give charity.' Then Allah will say to him: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say to him: 'You have lied.' Allah, Most High, will say: 'Rather, you wanted it to be said that so-and-so is so generous, and that was said.' Then the one who was killed in Allah's cause shall be brought, and Allah will say to him : 'For what were you killed?' So he says: 'I was commanded to fight in Your cause ,so I fought until I was killed.' Allah [Most High] will say to him: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say to him: 'You have lied.' Allah [Most High] will say: 'Rather, you wanted it be said that so-and-so is brave, and that was said.' 
"Then the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)hit me on my knees and said: 'O Abu Hurairah! These first three are the creatures of Allah with whom the fire will be enflamed on the Day of Judgement.'"
Al-Walid Abu 'Uthman Al-Mada'ini said: "So 'Uqbah bin Muslim informed me that Shaufaiy, is the one who entered upon Mu'awiyah to inform him about this." Abu Uthman said: 'This has been done with these people, then how about with those who remain among the people?"
